lines.meaning: The gathering has not come together as hoped. Genuine grief at the failure. But no fault lies with you.

description: Lake above earth — water gathering on the surface. This hexagram speaks of the power and necessity of gathering together. Communities, organizations, and movements require a center of devotion and strong leadership to coalesce and endure.

name: Sheng
judgment: Pushing Upward has supreme success. One must see the great person. Fear not. Departure toward the south brings good fortune.
image: Within the earth, wood grows: the image of Pushing Upward. Thus the superior person of devoted character heaps up small things in order to achieve something high and great.

lines.text: Pushing upward that meets with confidence brings great good fortune.
lines.meaning: Your ascent is trusted and welcomed by those above. Rise with confidence.

lines.text: If one is sincere, it furthers one to bring even a small offering. No blame.
lines.meaning: Sincerity substitutes for elaborate preparation. Even modest efforts further the ascent.

lines.text: One pushes upward into an empty city.
lines.meaning: Advancing without resistance. The path is clear and the destination unoccupied.

lines.text: The king offers him Mount Qi. Good fortune. No blame.
lines.meaning: Recognized by authority and given a place of honor. Elevation through merit.

lines.text: Perseverance brings good fortune. One pushes upward by steps.
lines.meaning: Steady, step-by-step advancement. Each stage builds on the last. Patience in rising.

lines.text: Pushing upward in darkness. It furthers one to be unremittingly persevering.
lines.meaning: Ascending blindly, without clear vision. Only relentless persistence avoids losing ground.

description: Earth above wind (wood) — a tree growing within the earth, pushing steadily upward. This hexagram represents gradual, determined ascent through consistent effort. Like a plant growing toward the light, pushing upward requires patience and persistent devotion.

name: Kun
judgment: Oppression. Success. Perseverance. The great person brings about good fortune. No blame. When one has something to say, it is not believed.
image: There is no water in the lake: the image of Exhaustion. Thus the superior person stakes their life on following their will.

lines.text: One sits oppressed under a bare tree and strays into a gloomy valley. For three years one sees nothing.
lines.meaning: Deep depression and isolation. Lost in darkness with no relief in sight.

lines.text: One is oppressed while at meat and drink. The person with the scarlet knee bands is just coming. It furthers one to offer sacrifice. To set forth brings misfortune. No blame.
lines.meaning: Oppressed even amid comfort. Help is approaching. Make offerings and wait; do not set out.

lines.text: One permits oneself to be oppressed by stone, and leans on thorns and thistles. One enters the house and does not see one's wife. Misfortune.
lines.meaning: Suffering from hard obstacles outside and finding no comfort at home. Complete misfortune.

lines.text: He comes very quietly, oppressed in a golden carriage. Humiliation, but the end is reached.
lines.meaning: Help arrives slowly and awkwardly. The delivery is embarrassing but the relief is real.

lines.text: His nose and feet are cut off. Oppression at the hands of the one with the purple knee bands. Joy comes softly. It furthers one to make offerings and libations.
lines.meaning: Severe oppression from authority. But gradually, relief comes. Maintain spiritual practice.

lines.text: He is oppressed by creeping vines. He moves uncertainly and says, 'Movement brings remorse.' If one feels remorse over this and makes a start, good fortune comes.
lines.meaning: Entangled in self-imposed constraints. Recognizing that regret itself can be a prison. Break free.

description: Lake above water — the lake has leaked away, leaving emptiness. This hexagram represents a time of extreme difficulty where resources are depleted and words go unheeded. Only the truly great can maintain their spirit and find success in such oppression.

name: Jing
judgment: The Well. The town may be changed, but the well cannot be changed. It neither decreases nor increases. They come and go and draw from the well. If one gets down almost to the water and the rope does not go all the way, or the jug breaks, it brings misfortune.
image: Water over wood: the image of the Well. Thus the superior person encourages the people at their work, and exhorts them to help one another.

lines.text: One does not drink the mud of the well. No animals come to an old well.
lines.meaning: A neglected source of wisdom. When the well is muddy, neither humans nor animals are drawn to it.

lines.text: At the wellhole one shoots fishes. The jug is broken and leaks.
lines.meaning: The well has water but the vessel is flawed. Potential exists but the means to access it are broken.

lines.text: The well is cleaned, but no one drinks from it. This is my heart's sorrow, for one might draw from it. If the king were clear-minded, good fortune might be enjoyed in common.
lines.meaning: The wisdom is there, purified and ready, but goes unused. A source of sorrow for the wise.

lines.text: The well is being lined. No blame.
lines.meaning: Repairing and maintaining the source. A time of inner work and renovation. Necessary and blameless.

lines.text: In the well there is a clear, cold spring from which one can drink.
lines.meaning: A pure, reliable source of wisdom and nourishment. Accessible to all who come.

lines.text: One draws from the well without hindrance. It is dependable. Supreme good fortune.
lines.meaning: The well is open, clear, and freely available. The highest good fortune comes from an inexhaustible source.

description: Water above wind (wood) — drawing water upward through a wooden bucket. The well represents the unchanging source of communal nourishment that serves all who come. Unlike the town which changes, the well endures. This hexagram speaks to the importance of maintaining access to deep, sustaining wisdom.

name: Ge
judgment: Revolution. On your own day you are believed. Supreme success, furthering through perseverance. Remorse disappears.
image: Fire in the lake: the image of Revolution. Thus the superior person sets the calendar in order and makes the seasons clear.

lines.text: Wrapped in the hide of a yellow cow.
lines.meaning: It is too early for revolution. Bind yourself with patience and wait for the proper time.

lines.text: When one's own day comes, one may create revolution. Starting brings good fortune. No blame.
lines.meaning: The time for change has arrived. Begin the revolution now. Action brings good fortune.

lines.text: Starting brings misfortune. Perseverance brings danger. When talk of revolution has gone the rounds three times, one may commit oneself, and others will believe.
lines.meaning: Do not rush. Let the idea of change circulate until consensus builds. Premature action fails.

lines.text: Remorse disappears. People believe him. Changing the form of government brings good fortune.
lines.meaning: Trust is established. Fundamental structural change is now possible and fortunate.

lines.text: The great person changes like a tiger. Even before questioning the oracle, they are believed.
lines.meaning: The leader transforms with the dramatic clarity of a tiger's stripes. Everyone can see the new pattern.

lines.text: The superior person changes like a panther. The inferior person molts in the face. Starting brings misfortune. To remain persevering brings good fortune.
lines.meaning: Refinement of the revolution in its final stages. No more dramatic changes needed. Settle and consolidate.

description: Lake above fire — fire and water in conflict, each trying to destroy the other. This hexagram represents fundamental change, the overthrow of the old by the new. Revolution must come at the right time, with the right preparation, and with genuine conviction.

name: Ding
judgment: The Caldron. Supreme good fortune. Success.
image: Fire over wood: the image of the Caldron. Thus the superior person consolidates their fate by making their position correct.

lines.text: A ting with legs upturned furthers removal of stagnating stuff. One takes a concubine for the sake of her son. No blame.
lines.meaning: Turning things upside down to clean out the old. Unconventional means to achieve a worthy end.

lines.text: There is food in the ting. My comrades are envious, but they cannot harm me. Good fortune.
lines.meaning: Real substance and nourishment attract envy. But genuine worth cannot be diminished by jealousy.

lines.text: The handle of the ting is altered. One is impeded in one's way of life. The fat of the pheasant is not eaten. Once rain falls, remorse is spent. Good fortune comes in the end.
lines.meaning: Your abilities go unrecognized. The finest offerings are neglected. But eventually the situation clears.

lines.text: The legs of the ting are broken. The prince's meal is spilled and his person is soiled. Misfortune.
lines.meaning: The vessel breaks under a task too great for it. Overloading capacity leads to a disastrous spill.

lines.text: The ting has yellow handles, golden carrying rings. Perseverance furthers.
lines.meaning: The vessel is complete with proper fittings. Everything is in place for serving its highest purpose.

lines.text: The ting has rings of jade. Great good fortune. Nothing that does not act to further.
lines.meaning: The vessel is perfect in both function and beauty. Supreme fortune in all endeavors.

description: Fire above wind (wood) — wood feeds fire, the image of the sacrificial caldron. The ting was the sacred vessel of ancient China, used to prepare offerings. This hexagram represents the transformation of raw materials into refined nourishment, both physical and spiritual.

name: Zhen
judgment: Shock brings success. Shock comes — oh, oh! Laughing words — ha, ha! The shock terrifies for a hundred miles, and he does not let fall the sacrificial spoon and chalice.
image: Thunder repeated: the image of Shock. Thus in fear and trembling the superior person sets their life in order and examines themselves.

lines.text: Shock comes — oh, oh! Then follow laughing words — ha, ha! Good fortune.
lines.meaning: The initial terror of shock gives way to relief and laughter. What seemed terrible proves beneficial.

lines.text: Shock comes bringing danger. A hundred thousand times you lose your treasures and must climb the nine hills. Do not go in pursuit of them. After seven days you will get them back.
lines.meaning: The shock causes massive loss. Do not chase what was lost. It will return naturally in time.

lines.text: Shock comes and makes one distraught. If shock spurs to action, one remains free of misfortune.
lines.meaning: The shock is disorienting. But if you let it motivate constructive action, no harm results.

lines.text: Shock is mired.
lines.meaning: The shock gets bogged down and loses its transformative power. Paralysis rather than awakening.

lines.text: Shock goes hither and thither. Danger. However, nothing at all is lost. Yet there are things to be done.
lines.meaning: Repeated shocks from every direction. Nothing is truly lost, but vigilance and action are required.

lines.text: Shock brings ruin and terrified gazing around. Going ahead brings misfortune. If it has not yet touched one's own body but has reached one's neighbor first, there is no blame. Companions have something to talk about.
lines.meaning: Total shock and paralysis. Do not advance. If the disaster hasn't hit you directly yet, learn from others' experience.

description: Thunder upon thunder — repeated shock. The first shock terrifies; the second awakens. This hexagram represents the power of sudden events to shake us out of complacency and catalyze self-examination and growth.

name: Gen
judgment: Keeping Still. Keeping his back so still that he no longer feels his body. He goes into his courtyard and does not see his people. No blame.
image: Mountains standing close together: the image of Keeping Still. Thus the superior person does not permit their thoughts to go beyond their situation.

lines.text: Keeping his toes still. No blame. Continued perseverance furthers.
lines.meaning: Stillness at the very beginning of movement. Stopping before the first step is blameless.

lines.text: Keeping his calves still. He cannot rescue him whom he follows. His heart is not glad.
lines.meaning: Forced to be still when you want to help someone. The frustration of being unable to act.

lines.text: Keeping his hips still. Making his sacrum stiff. Dangerous. The heart suffocates.
lines.meaning: Forced stillness in the center of the body creates rigidity that suffocates the spirit.

lines.text: Keeping his trunk still. No blame.
lines.meaning: Stillness of the whole torso. Meditation that calms the center. This is blameless.

lines.text: Keeping his jaws still. The words have order. Remorse disappears.
lines.meaning: Stillness of speech. When you still the urge to speak carelessly, words become measured and regret vanishes.

lines.text: Noble-hearted keeping still. Good fortune.
lines.meaning: The highest form of stillness, arising from inner peace and magnanimity. Supreme good fortune.

description: Mountain upon mountain — absolute stillness. This hexagram teaches the art of knowing when to stop. True stillness is not paralysis but the focused calm that comes when the restless mind finds its resting place. Each thought stays within its proper bounds.

name: Jian
judgment: Development. The maiden is given in marriage. Good fortune. Perseverance furthers.
image: On the mountain, a tree: the image of Development. Thus the superior person abides in dignity and virtue, in order to improve the mores.

lines.text: The wild goose gradually draws near the shore. The young son is in danger. There is talk. No blame.
lines.meaning: The first cautious step into new territory. Gossip may arise, but steady progress is blameless.

lines.text: The wild goose gradually draws near the cliff. Eating and drinking in peace and concord. Good fortune.
lines.meaning: Safe ground has been reached. A time of shared nourishment and harmonious progress.

lines.text: The wild goose gradually draws near the plateau. The man goes forth and does not return. The woman carries a child but does not bring it forth. Misfortune. It furthers one to fight off robbers.
lines.meaning: Premature advance leads to separation and incomplete outcomes. Protect what you have.

lines.text: The wild goose gradually draws near the tree. Perhaps it will find a flat branch. No blame.
lines.meaning: Finding an unusual resting place. Adapting to available circumstances, even if not ideal.

lines.text: The wild goose gradually draws near the summit. For three years the woman has no child. In the end nothing can hinder her. Good fortune.
lines.meaning: Near the peak but results are delayed. Patience through a long wait is eventually rewarded.

lines.text: The wild goose gradually draws near the cloud heights. Its feathers can be used for the sacred dance. Good fortune.
lines.meaning: The highest stage of development. Your journey becomes an inspiration and offering to others.

description: Wind above the mountain — a tree growing on a mountainside, slowly and steadily. Like the wild goose in gradual flight, this hexagram represents development that follows a natural, orderly progression. Each stage must be completed before the next begins.

name: Gui Mei
judgment: The Marrying Maiden. Undertakings bring misfortune. Nothing that would further.
image: Thunder over the lake: the image of the Marrying Maiden. Thus the superior person understands the transitory in the light of the eternity of the end.

lines.text: The marrying maiden as a concubine. A lame person who is able to tread. Undertakings bring good fortune.
lines.meaning: Accepting a subordinate position. Even with limitations, steady effort brings success.

lines.text: A one-eyed person who is able to see. The perseverance of a solitary person furthers.
lines.meaning: Limited vision but still able to perceive. Loyalty in solitude has its own rewards.

lines.text: The marrying maiden as a slave. She marries as a concubine.
lines.meaning: Entering a relationship in a demeaning position. Accepting less than one deserves.

lines.text: The marrying maiden draws out the allotted time. A late marriage comes in due course.
lines.meaning: Waiting past the usual time. Delayed fulfillment that comes through patience and integrity.

lines.text: The sovereign gave his daughter in marriage. The embroidered garments of the princess were not as gorgeous as those of the serving maid. The moon that is nearly full brings good fortune.
lines.meaning: True nobility is in the substance, not the appearance. Modest presentation conceals inner richness.

lines.text: The woman holds the basket, but there are no fruits. The man stabs the sheep, but no blood flows. Nothing that acts to further.
lines.meaning: Empty gestures. The forms are observed but the substance is missing. Ritual without meaning.

description: Thunder above the lake — the younger daughter follows the older. This hexagram addresses the difficulties of entering a relationship from a position of weakness. It speaks to obligations, compromises, and the wisdom of understanding one's true position.

name: Feng
judgment: Abundance has success. The king attains abundance. Be not sad. Be like the sun at midday.
image: Both thunder and lightning come: the image of Abundance. Thus the superior person decides lawsuits and carries out punishments.

lines.text: When a person meets the ruler who is his appointed match, they can remain together ten days, and it is not a mistake. Going meets with recognition.
lines.meaning: Meeting your perfect counterpart. Even an extended collaboration is appropriate and recognized.

lines.text: The curtain is of such fullness that the polestars can be seen at noon. Through going one meets with mistrust and hate. If one rouses him through truth, good fortune comes.
lines.meaning: Abundance so great it creates shadows. Truth alone can overcome the suspicion that comes with plenty.

lines.text: The underbrush is of such abundance that the small stars can be seen at noon. He breaks his right arm. No blame.
lines.meaning: So much growth that light is blocked. Capability is impaired. But this is circumstance, not fault.

lines.text: The curtain is of such fullness that the polestars can be seen at noon. He meets his ruler, who is of like kind. Good fortune.
lines.meaning: Despite the shadows, you find your true counterpart. Recognition amid obscurity brings fortune.

lines.text: Lines are coming. Blessing and fame draw near. Good fortune.
lines.meaning: Brilliant people are approaching. The attraction of your brightness draws talent and recognition.

lines.text: His house is in a state of abundance. He screens off his family. He peers through the gate and no longer perceives anyone. For three years he sees nothing. Misfortune.
lines.meaning: Wealth that isolates. Abundance used to wall oneself off leads to loneliness and misfortune.

description: Thunder above fire — both light and movement at their peak. Like the sun at its zenith, this hexagram represents the moment of greatest abundance. Be like the sun at midday: radiate fully and without reservation, for the peak does not last.

name: Lu
judgment: The Wanderer. Success through smallness. Perseverance brings good fortune to the wanderer.
image: Fire on the mountain: the image of the Wanderer. Thus the superior person is clear-minded and cautious in imposing penalties, and does not drag out lawsuits.

lines.text: If the wanderer busies himself with trivial things, he draws down misfortune upon himself.
lines.meaning: A stranger who meddles in petty affairs invites trouble. Keep to what matters.

lines.text: The wanderer comes to an inn. He has his property with him. He wins the steadfastness of a young servant.
lines.meaning: Finding temporary refuge. Your resources and character attract loyal assistance.

lines.text: The wanderer's inn burns down. He loses the steadfastness of his young servant. Danger.
lines.meaning: Your temporary refuge is destroyed. Even loyal helpers abandon you. Extreme danger.

lines.text: The wanderer rests in a shelter. He obtains his property and an ax. My heart is not glad.
lines.meaning: Basic needs are met and tools acquired, but this is survival, not home. Melancholy persists.

lines.text: He shoots a pheasant. It drops with the first arrow. In the end this brings both praise and office.
lines.meaning: A single well-aimed effort brings recognition. Skill demonstrated abroad earns honor.

lines.text: The bird's nest burns up. The wanderer laughs first, then must needs lament and weep. Through carelessness he loses his cow. Misfortune.
lines.meaning: Losing even your temporary home through negligence. Starting with frivolity and ending in tears.

description: Fire above the mountain — a grass fire that moves quickly and does not stay. This hexagram speaks to the condition of the wanderer, one who has no permanent home. The stranger must be cautious, modest, and quick to act, for they have no foundation to fall back upon.

name: Xun
judgment: The Gentle. Success through what is small. It furthers one to have somewhere to go. It furthers one to see the great person.
image: Winds following one upon the other: the image of the Gently Penetrating. Thus the superior person spreads their commands abroad and carries out their undertakings.

lines.text: In advancing and in retreating, the perseverance of a warrior furthers.
lines.meaning: Whether moving forward or back, military discipline and resolve are needed. Firm commitment to action.

lines.text: Penetration under the bed. Priests and magicians are used in great number. Good fortune. No blame.
lines.meaning: Searching in hidden places for the source of problems. Many forms of insight are needed to find it.

lines.text: Repeated penetration. Humiliation.
lines.meaning: Over-analyzing and second-guessing leads to paralysis and embarrassment. Too much deliberation.

lines.text: Remorse vanishes. During the hunt, three kinds of game are caught.
lines.meaning: Decisive action after careful preparation yields multiple rewards. Regret dissolves in achievement.

lines.text: Perseverance brings good fortune. Remorse vanishes. Nothing that does not further. No beginning, but an end. Before the change, three days. After the change, three days. Good fortune.
lines.meaning: Careful preparation before and follow-through after a change. The transformation is successful.

lines.text: Penetration under the bed. He loses his property and his ax. Perseverance brings misfortune.
lines.meaning: Probing too deeply into hidden things. Losing your tools and resources through over-investigation.

description: Wind upon wind — gentle, persistent penetration. Like wind that enters every crack, this hexagram represents the power of gentle, sustained influence. Not forceful or dramatic, but quietly persistent, it eventually reaches everywhere.

name: Dui
judgment: The Joyous. Success. Perseverance is favorable.
image: Lakes resting one on the other: the image of the Joyous. Thus the superior person joins with friends for discussion and practice.

lines.text: Contented joyousness. Good fortune.
lines.meaning: Quiet, self-contained joy that does not depend on externals. The most genuine form of happiness.

lines.text: Sincere joyousness. Good fortune. Remorse disappears.
lines.meaning: Joy grounded in sincerity. When pleasure is genuine and wholesome, all regret vanishes.

lines.text: Coming joyousness. Misfortune.
lines.meaning: Seeking joy from external sources. Pleasure that must be pursued or imported brings trouble.

lines.text: Joyousness that is weighed is not at peace. After ridding oneself of mistakes, one has joy.
lines.meaning: Deliberating over which pleasures to pursue creates unease. Eliminate errors and joy follows naturally.

lines.text: Sincerity toward disintegrating influences is dangerous.
lines.meaning: Trusting what is destructive is perilous. Even good faith cannot redeem a corrupting influence.

lines.text: Seductive joyousness.
lines.meaning: Joy that seduces and leads astray. Pleasure becomes an end in itself, losing all substance.

description: Lake upon lake — double joy, water connected. This hexagram speaks of the power of genuine joy shared between people. Like friends gathering to discuss and practice, true joyousness strengthens bonds and enriches life. But joy must be rooted in sincerity.

name: Huan
judgment: Dispersion. Success. The king approaches his temple. It furthers one to cross the great water. Perseverance furthers.
image: The wind drives over the water: the image of Dispersion. Thus the kings of old sacrificed to the Lord and built temples.

lines.text: He brings help with the strength of a horse. Good fortune.
lines.meaning: Swift, powerful assistance to disperse the hardness before it solidifies. Act quickly.

lines.text: At the dissolution, he hurries to that which supports him. Remorse disappears.
lines.meaning: When things are dissolving, rush to your foundation. Find your support and regret vanishes.

lines.text: He dissolves his self. No remorse.
lines.meaning: Letting go of ego and self-interest. When you dissolve personal ambition, no regret remains.

lines.text: He dissolves his bond with his group. Supreme good fortune. Dispersion leads in turn to accumulation. This is something that ordinary people do not think of.
lines.meaning: Breaking free from cliques to serve a larger purpose. What seems like loss becomes the seed of greater gathering.

lines.text: His loud cries are as dissolving as sweat. Dissolution! A king abides without blame.
lines.meaning: Great proclamations that dissolve stagnation like a healing fever. The leader who disperses hoarded resources acts rightly.

lines.text: He dissolves his blood. Departing, keeping at a distance, going out, is without blame.
lines.meaning: Dissolving the deepest bonds of kinship or blood. Sometimes complete departure is the only solution.

description: Wind above water — wind dispersing and stirring the surface. This hexagram speaks of dissolving rigidity, selfishness, and division. Through shared devotion to something greater than self, the hardness of the heart melts and people come together.

name: Jie
judgment: Limitation. Success. Galling limitation must not be persevered in.
image: Water over lake: the image of Limitation. Thus the superior person creates number and measure, and examines the nature of virtue and correct conduct.

lines.text: Not going out of the door and the courtyard is without blame.
lines.meaning: Knowing when not to go out. Self-imposed limitation at the right time prevents error.

lines.text: Not going out of the gate and the courtyard brings misfortune.
lines.meaning: The same limitation carried too far. What was wise restraint becomes harmful passivity.

lines.text: He who knows no limitation will have cause to lament. No blame.
lines.meaning: Failing to set limits leads to natural consequences. The pain is educational, not punitive.

lines.text: Contented limitation. Success.
lines.meaning: Accepting limits naturally and without struggle. When limitation feels right, it brings success.

lines.text: Sweet limitation brings good fortune. Going brings esteem.
lines.meaning: Limits that you apply to yourself before imposing on others. Leading by example in restraint.

lines.text: Galling limitation. Perseverance brings misfortune. Remorse disappears.
lines.meaning: Harsh, bitter limitations. Persisting in severity causes harm. But recognizing the error dissolves regret.

description: Water above the lake — the lake can hold only so much water before it overflows. This hexagram teaches the necessity and art of limitation. Proper measure and reasonable boundaries create the structure within which life flourishes.

name: Zhong Fu
judgment: Inner Truth. Pigs and fishes. Good fortune. It furthers one to cross the great water. Perseverance furthers.
image: Wind over lake: the image of Inner Truth. Thus the superior person discusses criminal cases in order to delay executions.

lines.text: Being prepared brings good fortune. If there are secret designs, it is disquieting.
lines.meaning: Readiness and openness bring fortune. Hidden agendas create anxiety and undermine trust.

lines.text: A crane calling in the shade. Its young answers it. I have a good goblet. I will share it with you.
lines.meaning: Inner truth radiates outward. Like a crane whose call is answered, sincerity evokes a sincere response.

lines.text: He finds a comrade. Now he beats the drum, now he stops. Now he sobs, now he sings.
lines.meaning: Depending on another for one's emotional state. Joy and sorrow follow the other's lead. Loss of center.

lines.text: The moon nearly at the full. The team horse goes astray. No blame.
lines.meaning: Approaching fullness, one of the pair breaks away. The loss is natural at this stage and carries no blame.

lines.text: He possesses truth, which links together. No blame.
lines.meaning: Truth that binds all people together. The power of genuine sincerity to create unbreakable bonds.

lines.text: Cockcrow penetrating to heaven. Perseverance brings misfortune.
lines.meaning: Words without substance reaching too high. Empty proclamations that claim divine authority. Continuing this brings ruin.

description: Wind above the lake — the wind stirs the lake because nothing separates them. The two open lines at the center show an empty, receptive heart. This hexagram teaches that inner truth, held with sincerity, can influence even the most stubborn and insensible beings, like pigs and fishes.

name: Xiao Guo
judgment: Preponderance of the Small. Success. Perseverance furthers. Small things may be done; great things should not be done. The flying bird brings the message: it is not well to strive upward, it is well to remain below. Great good fortune.
image: Thunder on the mountain: the image of Preponderance of the Small. Thus in his conduct the superior person gives preponderance to reverence. In bereavement he gives preponderance to grief. In his expenditures he gives preponderance to thrift.

lines.text: The bird meets with misfortune through flying.
lines.meaning: Attempting to soar beyond your station at the very beginning. Overambition at the wrong time leads to disaster.

lines.text: She passes by her ancestor and meets her ancestress. He does not reach his prince and meets the official. No blame.
lines.meaning: Missing the primary target but connecting with someone else of worth. An acceptable alternative.

lines.text: If one is not extraordinarily careful, somebody may come from behind and strike him. Misfortune.
lines.meaning: Insufficient caution invites attack from unexpected quarters. Vigilance in small matters is critical now.

lines.text: No blame. He meets him without passing by. Going brings danger. One must be on guard. Do not act. Be constantly persevering.
lines.meaning: A balanced encounter. But do not push forward. Maintain constant vigilance without taking aggressive action.

lines.text: Dense clouds, no rain from our western territory. The prince shoots and hits him who is in the cave.
lines.meaning: Conditions are not yet ripe for major rainfall. But a precise, targeted action reaches its mark.

lines.text: He passes him by, not meeting him. The flying bird leaves him. Misfortune. This means bad luck and injury.
lines.meaning: Missing the opportunity entirely. What you sought flies away. Overreach leads to loss and harm.

description: Thunder above the mountain — the small exceeds the great. Like a bird that should fly low rather than high, this hexagram counsels attending to small matters with great care rather than attempting grand things. In this time, modesty and attention to detail are the path to success.

name: Ji Ji
judgment: After Completion. Success in small matters. Perseverance furthers. At the beginning good fortune, at the end disorder.
image: Water over fire: the image of the condition in After Completion. Thus the superior person takes thought of misfortune and arms themselves against it in advance.

lines.text: He brakes his wheels. He gets his tail in the water. No blame.
lines.meaning: Slowing down at the moment of completion. Getting slightly wet but avoiding disaster through caution.

lines.text: The woman loses the curtain of her carriage. Do not run after it; on the seventh day you will get it.
lines.meaning: A small loss after completion. Do not chase it anxiously. What was lost will return naturally.

lines.text: The Illustrious Ancestor disciplined the Devil's Country. After three years he conquered it. Inferior people must not be employed.
lines.meaning: A great campaign after completion takes years. Use only the best people for the consolidation phase.

lines.text: The finest clothes turn to rags. Be careful all day long.
lines.meaning: Even the best deteriorates after completion. Vigilance is needed to maintain what has been achieved.

lines.text: The neighbor in the east who slaughters an ox does not attain as much real happiness as the neighbor in the west with their small offering.
lines.meaning: After completion, a humble sincere offering matters more than a lavish display. Substance over show.

lines.text: He gets his head in the water. Danger.
lines.meaning: Complete submersion. After the end, a careless plunge back into chaos. The cycle begins again dangerously.

description: Water above fire — every line in its proper place, each yang matched by a yin. Perfect order is achieved. But this is also the moment of greatest danger, for the only direction from perfect order is toward disorder. Eternal vigilance is the price of completion.

name: Wei Ji
judgment: Before Completion. Success. But if the little fox, after nearly completing the crossing, gets his tail in the water, there is nothing that would further.
image: Fire over water: the image of the condition Before Completion. Thus the superior person is careful in the differentiation of things, so that each finds its place.

lines.text: He gets his tail in the water. Humiliating.
lines.meaning: A premature attempt to complete the crossing. Failure at the very start of the final stage.

lines.text: He brakes his wheels. Perseverance brings good fortune.
lines.meaning: Restraining the urge to rush to completion. Patient preparation for the final push.

lines.text: Before completion, attack brings misfortune. It furthers one to cross the great water.
lines.meaning: Not yet ready for the final assault. But the grand crossing itself is favored when properly prepared.

lines.text: Perseverance brings good fortune. Remorse disappears. Shock, thus to discipline the Devil's Country. For three years, great realms are awarded.
lines.meaning: Decisive effort at the right moment. The great campaign succeeds after long preparation. Rich rewards follow.

lines.text: Perseverance brings good fortune. No remorse. The light of the superior person is true. Good fortune.
lines.meaning: The genuine light of character shines through. Steady virtue in the penultimate moment brings fortune.

lines.text: There is drinking of wine in genuine confidence. No blame. But if one wets one's head, one loses it, in truth.
lines.meaning: Celebration is warranted. But losing yourself in the celebration — going too far — destroys everything you achieved.

description: Fire above water — no line is in its proper place. Everything is in transition, moving toward completion but not yet arrived. The last hexagram of the I Ching teaches that completion is never truly final. Every ending contains a new beginning, and the cycle continues eternally.
